message:
In my lab, we're using some custom software for image acquisition for our imaging systems. The latest system's data throughput was > 3.2 GB/s. So, we were no longer able to acquire to SSDs without the software crashing* because their throughput is an order of magnitude less. 

I ended up turning off file caching and buffering** in the win32 file IO API, taking up ~35 gigs of RAM and setting them up as RAMdisk. I would stream to RAM this way, and then copy to disk after the fact. This setup limits the imaging session to ~ 10 seconds. The next step I'm taking is splitting the data writes over 2 PCIe SSDs. 

Is there anything I could do differently to handle this kind of throughput more efficiently? Do you perhaps know of some lossless compression algorithm that is fast enough? Something else?

* Crashing is because of the buffer overflows in the acquisition card and because the software sucks.
** If you ever want to do this, make sure that all the buffers you want to write to a file are page aligned. VirtualAlloc() lets you allocate page-aligned memory.

Can't you subdivided the system to multiple nodes ?
Can you add a GPU to the system ? Cuda enabled GPU's can do jpeg compression very well at very high speed

Would a RAID 0 array of SSDs (4x to 8x) be able to cope with the data rates? or to minimize the delay after the capture in RAM disk?
What are your SSDs throughput ?
how long the session usually is and what is the usual expected data buffer ?
